conclusion: To determine the number of moments when the speed of the particle is 5 m/s, we need to analyze the displacement-time graph provided.
The graph shows displacement x on the vertical axis and time t on the horizontal axis.
The displacement starts at x = 10 m at t = 0 and decreases to x = -10 m at t = 4 s.
Velocity is the derivative of displacement with respect to time, v(t) = dx/dt.
Speed is the absolute value of velocity, |v(t)|.
The graph is a curve, indicating that the velocity is not constant.

premise: The slope of the tangent to the curve at any point gives the velocity at that point.
conclusion: We need to find the points where the slope of the tangent (velocity) is ±5 m/s.

premise: The graph appears to be a quadratic curve, suggesting a parabolic motion.
conclusion: Assume the displacement function is quadratic: x(t) = at^2 + bt + c.

premise: The initial condition at t = 0 is x(0) = 10.
The final condition at t = 4 is x(4) = -10.
conclusion: The velocity function is the derivative: v(t) = d/dt(at^2 + bt + 10) = 2at + b.
This gives two equations: 2at + b = 5 and 2at + b = -5.

premise: Each solution to these equations represents a moment when the speed is 5 m/s.
conclusion: Since the graph is symmetric and parabolic, there will be two solutions for each equation within the interval 0 ≤ t ≤ 4.

premise: There are two moments when the speed is 5 m/s and two moments when the speed is -5 m/s.
conclusion: Therefore, there are a total of four moments when the speed is 5 m/s.
